issues.title: Curl error thrown f or http POST
Possible DoS using firefox profiles
issues.body:
### What are you trying to achieve? (Expected behavior)
Testing for XXE vulnerability in the Firefox extension loading. Should disallow entities

### What do you get instead? (Actual behavior)
Does not disallow entities and processes them

### How could the issue be reproduced? (Steps to reproduce)
To be very honest, I am not 100% sure of the workflow for this vulnerability's scenario (due to lack of knowledge of how to use the software, sorry for any mistakes). Basically when the Firefox profile is being encoded, all of the extensions are being installed using the installExtensions function
https://github.com/facebook/php-webdriver/blob/139980fb59bb0e48e47a1bc515ee4fb6e6848780/lib/Firefox/FirefoxProfile.php#L201
This extracts the extension's XPI file into a temporary directory and then uses `simplexml_load_file` to load in the XML (in order to extract the version number). If the `install.rdf` file contains a valid XXE payload (like the billion laughs attack https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Billion_laughs_attack), this can cause a DoS scenario (and possibly even code execution). 
https://github.com/facebook/php-webdriver/blob/139980fb59bb0e48e47a1bc515ee4fb6e6848780/lib/Firefox/FirefoxProfile.php#L209

### Remediation
Prior to loading any xml, disable entities ensuring that the above-mentioned attacks will no longer be possible.
`libxml_disable_entity_loader(true);`

### Details

* Php-webdriver version: 1.5.0
* PHP version: 7.2.0
* Selenium server version: 3.8.1
* Operating system: Ubuntu 16.04
* Browser used + version: Firefox

issues.title: Take element screenshot not implemented in php-webdriver
issues.body:
As per spec: https://w3c.github.io/webdriver/webdriver-spec.html#dfn-take-element-screenshot
Take element screenshot is not implemented in php-webdriver. It should use the following endpoint:

GET /session/{session id}/element/{element id}/screenshot

It provides a guide, but I think the method implementation is more efficient in usability.
(guide : https://github.com/facebook/php-webdriver/wiki/taking-full-screenshot-and-of-an-element)

If you agree with the need for implementation, can I implement it?

issues.title: Element visibility is not triggered by hovering another element
W3C WebDriver protocol support
issues.body:
This is an issue to plan and track progress of implementing [W3C WebDriver](https://w3c.github.io/webdriver/webdriver-spec.html) protocol into php-webdriver.

Currently, only legacy [JsonWire](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/wiki/JsonWireProtocol) (aka OSS) protocol is supported by php-webdriver. Selenium server 3.x translates the protocol if needed for the remote end (browser). However not everything is translated (like `actions()`), making some of the features not working with remote ends supporting only the W3C protocol (which is currently only GeckoDriver for Firefox 48+).

Also since Selenium 3.5 the translation is disabled by default. While it still could be enabled (by starting the server like `java -jar selenium-server-standalone-3.5.3.jar -enablePassThrough false`) it is only partial and temporary solution.

## The work would require eg.:
- add some more functional tests, to make sure we don't breake the old protocol while doing the necessary refactoring
- prepare handshake to detect whether the remote end is speaking JsonWire or W3C dialect (we need this to support the old browsers etc.)
- define common interface for Json and W3C protocol
- convert current implementation to use this interface
- implement adapter for the W3C protocol
- implement GeckodriverService or something like that to start geckodriver locally
...

## Resources
- [JsonWireProtocol vs. W3C WebDriver](https://github.com/facebook/php-webdriver/wiki/JsonWireProtocol-vs.-W3C-WebDriver)
- [ProtocolHandshake](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/java/client/src/org/openqa/selenium/remote/ProtocolHandshake.java) in java bindings
- [Handshake and capabilities resolving](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/blob/master/py/selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py#L252) in python bindings

issues.title: Convenience class for checkbox
issues.body:
Similary as we have [WebDriverSelect](https://github.com/facebook/php-webdriver/blob/community/lib/WebDriverSelect.php) for `<select>`, it may be handy to have also something like WebDriverCheckbox for `<input type="checkbox">` elements with helper methods:
- check
- uncheck
- isChecked

and maybe some more.

issues.title: Support local safaridriver from Safari 10.0
issues.body:
Safari could be started through Selenium Server as remote WebDriver.

Since Safari 10.0 ([see blogpost](https://webkit.org/blog/6900/webdriver-support-in-safari-10/)), however, it could also be started also locally, using binary "safaridriver" (as chrome, opera and geckodriver - see also #344, #342). This is already supported by other selenium language bindings, so we could support it as well.  

It would require creating new classes SafariDriver, SafariDriverService and SafariOptions - see [java bindings](https://github.com/SeleniumHQ/selenium/tree/c2a4dabfdf0a29a252c9dd33aa541c06c061a9d4/java/client/src/org/openqa/selenium/safari) as an example.

issues.title: UnknownCommandException mouseMoveTo when calling moveToElement()
issues.body:
### What are you trying to achieve? (Expected behavior)
Trigger an hover event by moving mouse to element coordinates.

### What do you get instead? (Actual behavior)
`UnknownCommandException: mouseMoveTo`

### How could the issue be reproduced? (Steps to reproduce)
<!-- Please fill everything relevant - the exact code you use, how you initialize the WebDriver, HTML snippet or URL of the page where you encounter the issue etc. -->

```php
$capabilities = DesiredCapabilities::firefox();
$driver = RemoteWebDriver::create('http://localhost:4444/wd/hub', $capabilities);

$driver->get("https://www.mozilla.org/en-US/");
$element = $driver->findElement(WebdriverBy::id("nav-button-menu"));
$driver->action()->moveToElement($element)->perform();
```

This looks like an old endpoint from the JsonWireProtocol which has been removed in some drivers (eg. IE and geckodriver). I think actions are the way to go now which I thought it was by calling `action()` method. 
IE and Geckodriver don't support the old APIs, so we'll have to implement w3c protocol in order to use latest versions of Selenium server.
Thank's for your help ;)

### Details

* Php-webdriver version: 1.4.1
* Selenium server version: 3.5.1
* InternetExplorerDriver: 3.5.1
* Geckodriver: 0.17.0
* PHP version: 5.6
* Operating system: Windows 10
* Browser used + version: Firefox 52, 56; IE 11

commits.message:
Add `CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md`

In the past Facebook didn't promote including a Code of Conduct when creating new projects, and many projects skipped this important document. Let's fix it. :)

**why make this change?:**
Facebook Open Source provides a Code of Conduct statement for all
projects to follow, to promote a welcoming and safe open source community.

Exposing the COC via a separate markdown file is a standard being
promoted by Github via the Community Profile in order to meet their Open
Source Guide's recommended community standards.

As you can see, adding this file will improve [the php-webdriver community profile](https://github.com/facebook/php-webdriver/community)
checklist and increase the visibility of our COC.

**test plan:**
Viewing it on my branch -
(Flarnie will insert screenshots)

**issue:**
internal task t23481323

Link to COC from `CONTRIBUTING.md`

We are about to add a `CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md` doc and it makes sense to surface it here.

during profile setup, some temporary files/folders are

prevent disk space issues.

Yes - it's part of the namespace syntax. The scope of the whole file is set by the namespace call at the beginning of the file. Since Exception is not defined in the WebDriver namespace, **_throw Exception(...)**_ fails. Instead they need to be fully qualified **_throw \Exception(...)**_.

See http://us3.php.net/manual/en/language.namespaces.rules.php for more information.

Here is a link to the Zend coding style where the naming convention for classes is outlined:

http://framework.zend.com/manual/en/coding-standard.naming-conventions.html
If you decide against namespacing, could you at least switch to WebDriver_ as the prefix for class names, so it follows the PEAR/ZF naming convention?

I think we should chalk this up as a protocol limitation.

By definition, an xpath that starts with a '/' is an absolute path relative to the root node, not the context node.  What you want to use is:

$txt = $session->element('id', 'base_element')->element('xpath', 'div[@class="descr"]')->text();

The possible values are documented in the JsonWireProtocol.  There's a link in the README, but I'll include it here for your convenience.

http://code.google.com/p/selenium/wiki/JsonWireProtocol

Seems totally reasonable, though I'm tempted in one way of looking at it to remove the $extra_opts argument to WebDriverBase::curl if no one uses it.

What would be perhaps more useful is to be able to set a variable to a path and have all the curl verbose info go there.  So instead of providing a general way to set curl options, there would be a specific way to tell WebDriver to set CURLOPT_VERBOSE and CURLOPT_STDERR (or whatever the combo of options actually is) and all the users of WebDriver would have to do is set a variable?

Could just be idle thoughts.  It might be useful enough though.  Seems like selenium is enough of a moving target these days that I spend more time debugging it or dealing with unpredictable / changing results than I do writing new tests (or new code for that matter).

I suppose you're right. If you have any insight, I'd love thoughts or ideas. I'll close the ticket, since it doesn't pertain to the webdriver itself, but more towards Selenium Server.

FYI, so far in trying out all the available PHP bindings for Web Driver, this one is the least user friendly in terms of API and examples of common usage. Can't say for overall feature support though, I'm only starting to evaluate right now, and to a novice, API interface makes a big difference in terms of usability.

I'm comparing to

http://code.google.com/p/php-webdriver-bindings/

https://github.com/chibimagic/WebDriver-PHP
Thanks, that will help some. I'll post to wiki what I know, etc.

curiouser, you might want to try other browsers like "internet explorer" as session argument and see how that works. For some reason I've run into issue with using Firefox browser with RemoteWebDriver (all bindings so far including this PHP one) and with FirefoxDriver Java binding (interestingly, it works fine in Python).

For me using Firefox, at the session initialization, it opens browser but dies with exception that connection reset. Same code with IE works fine. So you might want to check whether it's a quirk with that or whether it is really an issue with this PHP binding.

Um, jubishop, for Python, it was only working via the standard FirefoxDriver, not the RemoteWebDriver. And with the standard/local driver, you don't have to start a server, so don't think that really applies for my case.

Probably good to try with latest version of Selenium server as well. And technically, all client implementations of JSONWireProtocol are RemoteWebDrivers, hence this PHP binding could be considered one.

RemoteWebDriver & JSONWireProtocol = need to run Selenium standalone server (or as Grid2 hub + node config) to use WebDriver. The Firefox and InternetExplorer drivers specific to Java, Python, etc. don't require starting up a server.

That's a question to the original poster of this issue. I just added some comments based on my experience. But my Firefox issue is likely with the Selenium 2 Server itself, nothing to do with your PHP bindings.

You'd need to zip up the file of interest (to upload), then base64 encode that file to string/text, then pass that as an argument to a call to an undocumented JSONWireProtocol command (see the discussion link), check/parse the returned result for the location of the file on remote server then make a call to "sendKeys" passing the location result as argument. That should then perform the upload.

That's the general theoretical approach and should work. But I've not yet tested it out. By the way, I started that discussion.

because the package.xml is really hard to maintain, and till now, no such reliable PEAR tool for this.

by using Onion, we can generate the package.xml for PEAR installer very easily, through a 5~8 lines config file, then people can install it through Facebook's PEAR channel or install from command-line directly.

```
 $ vim package.ini
 $ onion.phar build 
 $ pear install -f package.xml
```

or 

```
 $ pear install facebook/WebDriver
```

To use WebDriver in one project as a dependency, can use Onion's bundle feature, for example:
1. define package.ini
2. run `onion.phar bundle`
3. WebDriver will be installed into the path `vendor/pear`.

To release this package on PEAR channel, can use Prium (PEAR channel builder)
1. define pirum pirum.xml (5~10 lines xml)
2. run pirum add package
3. run prium build

Sure. In this [[page](http://php.net/manual/en/language.oop5.typehinting.php)], there is a line.

```
Type hints can not be used with scalar types such as int or string.
```

We can force parameters to be objects but not scalar. If `int` is used as the type hint, there is an error whenever WebDriverWait is constructed.

```
$wait = new WebDriverWait($driver, 10);
```

```
Catchable fatal error: Argument 2 passed to WebDriverWait::__construct() must
be an instance of int, integer given, called in /path/to/your/file.php on line 12 and
defined in /path/to/php-webdriver/lib/WebDriverWait.php on line 29
```

There is a problem here.
If an extra option was set in the previous command, the option will be set in all commands after that.
If I set the timeout of the previous request to be 10s, all requests will have timeout 10s after that.

What is the problem of using `user.js`? 
According to mozilla (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Preferences/A_brief_guide_to_Mozilla_preferences), 

```
In the profile directory are two user pref files: prefs.js and user.js.  prefs.js is automatically generated by the application and should not be edited manually, whereas user.js is an optional file the user can create to override preferences initialized by other preferences files.
```

It looks more correct to use `user.js`. Also, the official Java binding is also using `user.js`.

Good catch! Due to the fact that the original specs you provided specify that this Expected Condition should return bool true on pass, bool false on fail I changed the code instead of the doc-block.

[strpos](http://php.net/manual/en/function.strpos.php) returns the location of the substring in the original string when found, false otherwise. I took advantage of this behavior simply returning the result of a conditional checking for false so that we always receive a bool.

Also note this is not precisely to spec. The original seems to be a void function. I wasn't certain if lack of a return value would break the wait functionality, so I made it with boiler-plate returns (true for pass, false for fail)

I didn't know about `WebDriverWait::until()` to be perfectly honest. After reviewing them they're functionally the same.

`WebDriverExpecedCondition::custom()` does still allow the creation of custom WebDriverExpectedCondition objects without compromising the protected constructor. It's not necessary as it's just an extra layer for the user (ie. passing the closure into the expected condition into until instead of just passing the closure to until) but it allows programmers to achieve greater consistency, and apply DDD concepts to their code (everything passed into until is the same object).
